newsitem.title: USA: Hortense becomes hurricane, cleanup from Fran goes on.
newsitem.headline: Hortense becomes hurricane, cleanup from Fran goes on.

text.p: Tropical Storm Hortense became a hurricane on Monday south of the U.S. Virgin Islands as North Carolina residents faced a huge cleanup job after Hurricane Fran.
At 5 a.m. EDT (0900 GMT), Hortense became a hurricane, according to the National Hurricane Center in Miami, with winds of 80 miles per hour (128 kph).
It was moving west-northwest at seven mph (12 kph), said meteorologist Colin McAdie and was 120 miles (193 km) south of St. Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands.
Hortense was on a track to pass over the island of Hispaniola, home of Haiti and the Dominican Republic "sometime within the next day or two" McAdie said.
In North Carolina, workers were replacing hundreds of miles (kilometres) of downed power lines, repairing roads and hauling away fallen trees and debris.
Washington, however, was bracing itself for the fallout from Fran as rising floodwaters in the Potomac River threatened the nation's capital on Sunday.

Flooded streets near the river caused the closing of the Vietnam War Memorial and residents of the metropolitan area awoke (on) Monday to a traffic nightmare of closed arterial roads and cancelled trains.
Across the river in Virginia, picturesque Oldtown Alexandria was shut down by flooding.

Fran dumped four inches (10 cm) of rain in the capital and up to 14 inches (35 cm) in outlying areas, forecasters predicted a flood surge of 13 to 15 feet (4-4.5 metres) in the wealthy Georgetown section of the city and up to 34 feet (10 metres) at Harpers Ferry, West Virginia.
Hurricane Fran cut a swathe of destruction from Cape Fear on the southeastern end of North Carolina, where it came ashore, to the northwest of the state.

At least 15 people were killed in the state, including a firefighter and Marine, "and there may be more," Sara Kempin, a spokeswoman for North Carolina Emergency Management Center, said. Some drowned and others were killed when trees fell on their cars or houses, she said.

"The devastation is widespread across coastal and inland counties, and I want to do all we can to help rebuild North Carolina and help our people get their lives back together," Gov. Jim Hunt said in a statement.
There were 728,667 customers still without power throughout the state, and electric utility crews from Georgia, Ohio, Kentucky, Tennessee and West Virginia were on hand to help restore power.
Airspace over the beaches hardest hit by Fran has been closed, since sightseers were deemed to be posing a hazard to airborne disaster relief crews.

"A no-fly zone has been established from two miles offshore to two miles inland from the New River Inlet south to Holden Beach," William Dudley, state deputy secretary of Crime Control and Public Safety, said.
In Wrightsville Beach, a town on a barrier island off Wilmington, officials said safety concerns would keep residents from returning for at least three days.
On Topsail Island, north of Wilmington, rescue workers searched homes in North Topsail Beach for missing people.
The Wilmington (N.C.) City Council passed an emergency ordinance on Saturday to prevent price gouging, making it punishable by a $500 fine or 30 days in jail.
